title-group.article-title: Finite element buckling analysis of laminated composite sandwich panels with transversely flexible core carrying attached elastic strip

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Structural Analysis and Simulation, Space Research Center, Tehran, Iran
2Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Ryerson University, Toronto, ON, Canada
3Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ryerson University, Toronto, ON, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Habiba Bougherara, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Ryerson University, Toronto, ON M5B 2K3, Canada. Email: habiba.bougherara@ryerson.ca

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this article, a three-dimensional finite element model is proposed to study the effect of distributed attached mass with thickness and stiffness on the buckling instability of sandwich panels with transversely flexible cores. Unlike the previous works in the literature which have made use of unified displacement theories, the present model uses different types of finite elements to model the core and the face sheets. It utilizes shell elements for the face sheets and three-dimensional solid elements for the core which enables the model to account for the transverse flexibility of the structure. The motions of the face sheets and the core as well as the attached mass are related through defining constraint equations between the nodes of their respective finite elements based on the concept of master and slave nodes which is incorporated into the finite element analysis program ANSYS through a user-defined subroutine. The validated finite element model is then used to study the effects of size, thickness, material property, aspect ratio, and the position of the attached mass on the buckling load of a sandwich panel under different combinations of boundary conditions. The results presented in this study have hitherto not been reported in the literature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structural efficiency is an important attribute for aircraft structures. Sandwich structures with composite-laminated face sheets and a transversely flexible core such as foam or low-strength honeycombs have long been known to have the potential for high structural efficiency and have extensively been used in stiffness-critical aircraft secondary structures [1]. Driven by stringent weight saving requirements, composite sandwich constructions have evolved as one of the basic structural design concepts for load-carrying components in aerospace engineering, civil engineering, and mechanical structures. In particular, constrained flexible structures having one or several attachments are often encountered in engineering applications: from plates supporting machinery such as electromechanical engines, planes and space structures carrying sensors, and actuators of different types to printed circuit boards with electronic elements attached to them. These structural components can be approximated as rectangular plates carrying distributed attached mass, which may be subjected to different modes of loading [2]. Attached mass can also be used as a remedy for a defect, e.g. a crack on the surface of a structure or to control the response of the structure to a certain type of loading. Under certain loading conditions, the instability of the structure may lead to its failure well before the ultimate strength is reached. Specifically, in case of sandwich structures with soft cores, the transverse flexibility of the panel as a result of the soft core leads to instabilities more complex than those for panels with rigid cores [1].

This article develops a finite element model to study the effect of distributed attached mass on the buckling instability of sandwich panels with transversely flexible cores. A large number of studies have been carried out to investigate the buckling of sandwich panels with a soft core. Hadi and Matthews [3] utilized a zig-zag model for through-thickness displacement, to include the transverse shear deformation of the face sheets. Yuan and Dawe [4, 5] developed a B-spline finite strip model in which the face sheets are modeled using the first-order shear deformation theory (FSDT) or the classical lamination plate theory and the core is modeled as a solid through linear three-dimensional (3D) theory of elasticity. Frostig [6] obtained the closed-form solution for the buckling load of simply supported sandwich panel using a higher-order theory to account for the nonlinear distortion of the core cross section as well as the change in its height. Dafedar et al. [7] proposed a unified, mixed higher-order analytical formulation eliminating thin stiff layers, and anti-plane core to predict the buckling instability of sandwich structures. Aiello and Ombres [1] presented an analytical approach based on an equivalent single layer approach assuming linear variation of all displacement components through the thickness and the buckling load was calculated using the Rayleigh–Ritz method.

The analytical models developed in the above-mentioned references, despite all the modifications, are based on unified displacement models which are not suitable to accurately model a thick panel with a transversely flexible core sandwiched in between two stiff face plates. A detailed review on the analytical methods in sandwich panel modeling is given in Noor et al. [8]. Since analytical models are capable of modeling only certain boundary conditions and fail to model complex geometries, it is natural to resort to numerical techniques such as the finite element method to solve a wider range of problems for instance for certain combinations of boundary conditions on the edges of the panel. Finite element solutions for multilayered sandwich plates were presented by Khatua and Cheung [9] using triangular and rectangular finite elements, which permit freedom of in-plane displacements for all stiff layers which eliminate the assumption of common shear angles. The finite element models based on the works of Khatua and Cheung have the major restriction of requiring C1 continuity. Nayak et al. [10] developed a C0 strain finite element based on Reddy’s higher-order theory to determine the natural frequencies of isotropic, orthotropic, and layered anisotropic composite and sandwich plates. While there are a few works on the effect of attached mass on the free vibration of composite laminates [2, 11], to the best of the author’s knowledge no research has yet investigated the effect of attached mass on the buckling load of sandwich structures with transversely flexible cores.

This article presents a novel finite element model by means of a user-defined subroutine incorporated in the finite element program ANSYS to study the effect of the size, material properties, shape, and position of distributed attached mass on the normal buckling response of sandwich structures subject to different boundary conditions on the top and bottom face sheets. Subsequent papers will investigate the effect of attached mass on the biaxial, shear and combined shear, and normal buckling of sandwich structures. In the finite element model presented in this study, the motion of the face sheet is related to the motion of the core through constraint equations utilizing the concept of slave and master nodes thus representing a more realistic model of the structure. The face sheets are modeled with shell elements and the core is modeled with 3D solid elements. The use of solid elements for modeling the core leads not only to more accuracy in the results, but also enables the model to account for the transverse flexibility of the structure. Relating the motion of the face sheets by means of constraint equations to the core renders this model the potential to study delamination between the core and the face sheets. In particular, certain boundary conditions that may not be studied analytically can be studied using the present finite element model. Numerical results that hitherto have not been reported in the literature have been presented in this article.

sec.title: Finite element model
sec.p: The element type used to model the composite face sheets and the distributed attached mass on the top face sheet of the sandwich plate is the eight-node layered structural shell 99. The element has six degrees of freedom at each node: translations in the nodal x-, y-, and z-directions, (Ux, Uy, and Uz) and rotations about the nodal x-, y-, and z-axes (θx, θy, and θz). By default, the nodes are placed at the middle surface of the element. This element is based upon the following assumptions: normal lines to the center-plane of face sheets are assumed to remain straight after deformation. Each pair of the integration points (in the z-direction) is assumed to have the same material orientation. The core is modeled using the higher-order solid 95 element. This element is defined by 20 nodes each having three degrees of freedom, translations in the nodal x-, y-, and z-directions. It can tolerate irregular shapes without as much loss of accuracy and has compatible displacement shapes and is well suited to model curved boundaries. The shell elements by default place the nodes at the mid-plane of the top and the bottom face sheets. If the nodes of the shell elements were shared with the solid brick element, half of the face sheet element in the thickness direction would penetrate into the solid brick element which would therefore result in a wrong representation of the actual structure. This problem can be removed through the use of user-defined constraint equations which relate the degree of freedom values together. A useful concept for constraint equations is that of master and slave nodes. The displacement of the slave node can be described in terms of the displacement of the master node [12]. Once the constraint is specified, only one of the two nodes whose motions are to be related is retained in the matrix system of equations, which is called the master node, while the remaining node is called the slave node. The above-mentioned concept is implemented into finite element program ANSYS through a user-defined code.

Through the use of the above-mentioned elements, the model uses the FSDT for the face sheets and a 3D elasticity theory for the core. The kinematic relations for the face sheets are (1)uj(x,y,z,t)=u0j(x,y,t)+zψxj(x,y,t)vj(x,y,z,t)=v0j(x,y,t)+zψyj(x,y,t)wj(x,y,z,t)=w0j(x,y,t) where u0,v0,andw0 represent the mid-plane displacements of the face sheet laminate along the x-, y-, and, z-axes, respectively. Subscript j=t,b denotes the top or the bottom face sheet, respectively, and ψx and ψy the rotations of the transverse normal about the y- and x-axes of the mid-plane of the face sheets which, for very thin plates, can be estimated as [13] (2)ψx=-∂w0∂xψy=-∂w0∂y

The kinematic relations for the core based on the small deformation theory, read (3)γxzc=∂uc∂z+∂wc∂xγyzc=∂vc∂z+∂wc∂y ɛzzc=∂wc∂z where uc(x,y,z,t),vc(x,y,z,t), and wc(x,y,z,t) are the in-plane longitudinal and vertical deflections of the core, respectively.

The compatibility conditions assuming perfect bonding between the core and the face sheets at the upper and lower interfaces with the coordinate system placed at the center of the mid-plane of the top face sheet require that uc(z=-ht2)=u0t-(ht2)ψxt uc(z=-ht2-hb2-hc)=u0b+(hb2)ψxb vc(z=-ht2)=v0t-(ht2)ψyt vc(z=-ht2-hb2-hc)=v0b+(hb2)ψyb wc(z=-ht2)=w0t wc(z=-ht2-hb2-hc)=w0b<label>(4)</label> where ht,hb, and hc are the top and the bottom face sheet thicknesses and the core thickness, respectively.

Through the above-mentioned equations, the mid-plane nodes of the top and the bottom face sheets are related to the upper and lower surfaces of the core, respectively, using the constraint equations. The distributed attached mass is modeled through the same procedure of applying constraint equations to relate the motion of the attached mass to the face sheet. Figure 1 shows a schematic representation of the sandwich panel with an attached mass on the top face sheet. Figure 1.
Schematic representation of the sandwich panel with an attached mass on the top face sheet.

sec.title: Overview of the finite element buckling analysis
sec.p: Buckling occurs when the membrane strain energy of a structure is converted into strain energy without any change of the externally applied load [14]. The stiffness matrix in a finite element buckling analysis is made up of two parts (5)[K]=[K0]+[Kσ] [K0] is the conventional stiffness matrix whose elements are independent of the structural displacement field and state of stress. [Kσ] is the stress-stiffness matrix which is dependent on the displacement field as well as the state of stress. The total stiffness matrix is associated with a specific equilibrium point at any configuration. During buckling, an infinitesimal displacement [dU] takes place from a reference configuration [U], without any change in the externally applied load which can be expressed as (6)([K0]+[Kσ])[dU]=0

A reference stress-stiffness matrix [Kσ]ref can be calculated through a static finite element analysis corresponding to a reference load [F]ref. For another load level, e.g. [F]=λ[F]ref, the stress-stiffness matrix may be found according to (7)[Kσ]=λ[Kσ]ref
Since the external load does not change during the infinitesimal buckling displacement, equation (6) may be written as (8)([K0]+λ[Kσ]ref)[dU]=0
This indicates an eigenvalue problem whose lowest eigenvalue yields the critical buckling load (9)[F]cr=λcr[F]ref

sec.title: Validation
sec.p:
First the results are validated for the case of sandwich structures without attached mass. Mahfuz and Seifulislam [15] calculated the buckling load of sandwich panels with three different foam core materials experimentally. Three layers of plane weave S2 glass fibers were used in each face sheet. Simply supported boundary conditions were imposed on the two shorter edges while the other two edges were left free. The material properties and the dimensions of the panel are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. Table 3 presents the results of the present model versus the experimentally calculated buckling loads in Mahfuz and Seifulislam [15]. As it can be seen, there is good agreement between the results and that the critical buckling load increases with core density. Table 1.
Core and face sheet properties [15]
Core (Klegcell foam) Face sheet (plain weave S2 glass fibers)
Core type R-75 R-130 R-260 E1=E2(GPa) 23.9
Density (kg/m3) 75 130 260 E3(GPa) 2.97
E(MPa) 38 120 283 ν12 0.12
G(MPa) 29 49 105 ν13=ν23 0.095
ν 0.32 0.32 0.32 G12(GPa) 7.58
G13=G23(GPa) 2.76
Table 2.
Sandwich panel dimensions [15]
a(mm): length of the panel 520.7
b(mm): width of the panel 254
hc(mm): core thickness 12.7
tf(mm): face sheet thickness 1.905
Table 3.
Comparison of critical buckling loads with experimental results
Buckling load (kN)/core R-75 R-130 R-260
Experimental [15] 34.3 ± 1.7 37.8 ± 1.93 45.4 ± 3.12
Present 33.08 37.22 41.35

In Table 4, the results are compared with 3D elastic solution [8] as well as with Aiello and Ombres [1] where the buckling load was calculated based on an equivalent single layer approach using the Rayleigh–Ritz method. The results obtained from the present analysis are seen to be in good agreement with the 3D elasticity solution especially even for higher values of tf/h which is the result of capturing the transverse flexibility of the core compared to Aiello and Ombres [1]. Table 4.
Dimensionless buckling load p=Pxb2/E22h3 for a simply supported square sandwich panel
tf/h a/h Aiello and Ombres [1] Noor et al. [8] 3D elasticity Present
0.025 20 2.5480 2.5543 2.5147
10 2.2350 2.2376 2.1204
0.050 20 4.7026 4.6590 4.5677
10 3.9080 3.7375 3.5161
0.100 20 8.3220 7.8969 7.7419
10 6.5425 5.6081 5.4625
Notes: Lay-up: (0/90)5/core/(0/90)5.
Face sheets: E11/E22=19, G12/E22=0.52, G13/E22=0.52, G23/E22=0.338, ν12=ν13=0.32, and ν23=0.49.
Core: E1c/E22=3.2×10-5, E2c/E22=2.9×10-5, E3c/E22=0.4, G12c/E22=2.4×10-3, G13c/E22=7.9×10-2, G23c/E22=6.6×10-2, ν12c=0.99, and ν23c=ν13c=3×10-5.

Since hitherto, there have been no results on the effect of attached mass on the buckling response of sandwich structures in the literature; the validation for the case of sandwich structures with attached mass is carried out by increasing the area of the attached mass from zero until it covers the whole face sheet. This, indeed, should be almost equivalent to adding one more layer to the top face sheet with the same properties as those of the attached mass. Figure 2 shows the ratio of the buckling load of the sandwich panel with attached mass to the target load, i.e. the buckling load of a sandwich structure without attached mass, having an additional layer on the face sheet, for different area ratios. It is obvious that as the size of the attached mass increases, the buckling load approaches the target load. The reason why there is a slight difference between the buckling and target loads is because of the fact that an attached mass covering the whole face sheet is subjected to no boundary condition (in this case simply supported) on its edges, i.e. the attached mass is one extra layer with free edges on the top face sheet laminate. However, the target load is the buckling load of a sandwich structure without an attached mass where the edges of all layers of the face sheet are constrained. Figure 2.
The ratio of the buckling load of the sandwich panel with attached mass to the buckling load of a sandwich structure without attached mass, having an additional layer on the face sheet, versus different area ratios.

sec.title: The effect of the size of the attached mass on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the dimensionless critical buckling load (as defined in Table 4) of a simply supported square sandwich structure carrying a uniformly distributed square attached mass on the center of its top face sheet for different ratios of the attached mass area to the area of the face sheet. The material properties of the panel are given in Table 4. The attached mass is assumed to have the same properties and thickness as the top face sheet. It can be seen that increasing the size of the attached mass raises the stiffness and thus the buckling load of the structure. However, the slope of this increase becomes less significant for lager areas of the attached mass. This alludes to the role of attached mass as a constraint to control the buckling instability of sandwich structures. Figure 4 shows the 3D vertical deflection of the top face sheet corresponding to the critical buckling mode of a sandwich panels with and without attached mass. The vertical mid-span deflection of the top face sheet for three different attached mass areas are depicted in Figure 5. Due to symmetry only a quarter of the panel has been modeled. Figure 5.
Vertical mid-span deflection of the top face sheet. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1. Figure 3.
The effect of the attached mass size on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1.

sec.title: The effect of the attached mass material property on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
The effect of the attached mass material property on the dimensionless critical buckling load of a simply supported square sandwich structure is shown in Figure 6 for three different area ratios. The attached mass is located on the center of the top face sheet and is assumed to be isotropic with the same thickness as the top face sheet. The material properties of the panel are given in Table 4. Increasing the stiffness of the attached mass is seen to increase the buckling load of the structure due to the rise in the local bending stiffness in the region where the mass is attached. It is also observed that the rate of this rise, which is more noticeable for larger masses, reduces with increasing the stiffness of the attached mass. Figure 4.
Vertical deflection of the top face sheet corresponding to the critical buckling mode of a sandwich panels with and without attached mass.

sec.title: The effect of the attached mass thickness on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p: Another factor affecting the buckling instability of a sandwich structure is the thickness of the distributed attached mass. The variations of the dimensionless critical buckling load of a simply supported square sandwich panel carrying an attached mass on the center of its face sheet with the thickness of the attached mass is shown in Figure 7. The properties of the attached mass are assumed to be the same as those of the face sheet. The material properties of the panel are given in Table 4. It is seen that except for small thicknesses, increasing the thickness of the attached mass does not significantly affect the buckling stability of the structure. However, the effect of the thickness becomes more pronounced as the attached mass gets larger.

sec.title: The effect of the attached mass aspect ratio on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
The variations of the dimensionless critical buckling load versus the aspect ratio of a sandwich panel for a fixed attached mass area are shown in Figure 8. Figure 9 shows the effect of the attached mass aspect ratio (am/bm) on the critical buckling load of a simply supported square sandwich panel carrying a uniformly distributed attached mass located on its center for different area ratios. Aspect ratios greater than 1 represent rectangular attached mass in longitudinal directions and aspect ratios smaller than 1 corresponds to rectangular attached mass in the transverse direction. Apart from the fact that the critical buckling load increases with increasing the area of the attached mass, the square attached mass is seen to result in the highest buckling load since the local stiffness of the panel increases equally in both dimensions. A closer examination of the graph reveals that panels with longitudinally oriented attached mass are more vulnerable to buckling failure compared to panels with transverse attached mass. This is because a larger region of increased stiffness is created in the central part of the panel perpendicular to the load in the case transversely oriented attached mass. Figure 7.
The effect of the attached mass thickness on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1. Figure 6.
The effect of the attached mass material property on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1.

sec.title: The effect of the attached mass location on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
Table 5 lists the dimensionless critical buckling loads of a simply supported sandwich panel carrying an attached mass at different locations illustrated in Figure 10. It is seen that that the critical buckling load is maximum when the attached mass is located at the center of the panel. The second highest buckling load corresponds to position E which is the closest to the center. It can also be observed that the attached mass at position D results in a higher buckling resistance compared to position B which is longitudinal to the load. Table 5.
The effect of the attached mass location on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
Position Dimensionless critical buckling load
Panel without attached mass 4.5677
Position A 4.7424
Position B 4.6028
Position C 4.6072
Position D 4.6201
Position E 4.6325
Note: a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, am/bm=1, and Am/A=0.04.
Figure 8.
The effect of the panel aspect ratio on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1.

sec.title: The effect of boundary conditions on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
One advantage of the present finite element model lies in its capability of modeling different combinations of boundary conditions some of which may not be modeled using analytical methods. To study the effect of the boundary conditions on the buckling stability of the sandwich panel, five different combinations of free, simply supported, and clamped-edge boundary conditions, as shown in Figure 11, have been taken into account. The letters F, S, and C denote free, simply supported, and clamped edges, respectively. Figure 12 shows the critical dimensionless buckling load of a sandwich panel subject to different boundary conditions for different area ratios. It is observed that the buckling load increases with greater geometric constraints imposed on the edges of the top and bottom face sheet as a result of increasing the bending stiffness of the panel with CSSS and SFFS leading to the highest and lowest buckling loads, respectively. Figure 9.
The effect of the attached mass aspect ratio on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, and a/h=20. Figure 10.
Different locations of the attached mass on the top face sheet of the sandwich panel.

sec.title: The effect of fiber angle on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel
sec.p:
In this section, the effect of the fiber orientation of the composite face sheets is depicted in Figure 13 for a sandwich panel carrying an attached mass on the center of its top face sheets for three different mass sizes. It is assumed that the attached mass possesses the same properties and thickness as the top face sheet. As shown in the figure, the worst case, i.e. the lowest buckling load corresponds to θ=30 and the highest buckling load corresponds to the cross-ply face sheets θ=0 and θ=90. When θ=0, fibers are aligned in the load direction and therefore reinforce the panel against buckling. Increasing the fiber angle will decrease this reinforcement in the load direction resulting in a lower buckling resistance. However, after a certain angle, the panel starts being reinforced in the direction perpendicular to the load and therefore resistance to buckling starts to increase so that at θ=90, since there is no risk of fiber buckling as compared to when θ=0, the critical buckling load reaches its maximum value. Figure 11.
Different combinations of boundary conditions on the face sheets of the sandwich panel. Figure 12.
The effect of boundary conditions on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, and am/bm=1. Figure 13.
The effect of fiber angle on the critical buckling load of the sandwich panel. a/b=1, tf/h=0.050, a/h=20, am/bm=1, and (0/θ)5/core/(0/θ)5.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A novel finite element model to investigate the buckling instability of sandwich panels with transversely flexible cores, carrying a uniformly distributed attached mass with stiffness and thickness, has been presented. Unlike the previous works in the literature which have made use of unified displacement, the present model uses different types of finite elements to model the core and the face sheets. It utilizes shell elements for the face sheets and solid elements for the core. The motions of the face sheets and the core are related through defining constraint equations between the nodes of their respective finite elements based on the concept of master and slave nodes. In particular, the use of solid elements enables the model to capture the transverse flexibility of the core and makes it suitable for relatively thick panels. The same concept of master and slave nodes is implemented to model the attached mass with thickness and stiffness. Since hitherto, there have been no results on the effect of attached mass on the buckling response of sandwich structures in the literature; validation is made through comparison with buckling loads of sandwich structures without attached mass. It is found that the present results are in good agreement with the 3D elasticity solutions [8], in particular for higher values of tf/h, as opposed to the previous works. The model is then used to study the effect of the size, material properties, shape, and position of distributed attached mass on the normal buckling response of sandwich structures subject to different boundary conditions on the top and bottom face sheets. It is observed that the very existence of the attached mass increases the buckling resistance of the structure alluding to its role as a remedy for a defect, e.g. a crack on the surface of a structure or to control the response of the structure to buckling. Increasing the size, stiffness, and thickness of the attached mass is seen to raise the critical buckling load of the structure. For a fixed area of an attached mass, panels with a longitudinally oriented attached mass are more vulnerable to buckling failure compared to panels with a transverse attached mass. It is also observed that changing the location of the attached mass affects the critical buckling load of the structures so that an attached mass closer to the center results in a higher buckling load. However, the attached mass located on the line of symmetry of the panel perpendicular to the load direction is seen to result in a higher load compared to the attached mass located on the symmetry line parallel to the loading direction. The results also show that increased geometrical constraints imposed in form of boundary conditions on the face sheet cause to buckling load to rise. Variation of the fiber orientation of the face sheets and the attached mass which is assumed to be of the same thickness and properties of the face sheet shows that the lowest buckling loads corresponds to an angle ply face sheet when θ=30, whereas the highest buckling resistance occurs for cross-ply face sheets.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The research presented in this paper is funded by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC Discovery Grant Program).
